array cluster observability tools like

system so that you can effectively debug
and optimize your applications so let's
get started here's what the ray
dashboard looks like and as you can see
it's a web-based interface that gives
you a real-time view of your array
cluster
you can access the dashboard in a few
ways if you're an open source user each
time you initialize array cluster with
ray.init the dashboard will be hosted by
default at localhost 8265.
you'll need to set up Prometheus and
grafana in order to view these time
series metrics like the ones I have here
and you can find instructions in the
right documentation for doing so if
you're using the any skill console the
dashboard is accessible via your tools
Tab and the time series metrics will be

before we begin let's talk about

into several tabs at the top of your

will go through each of these in turn
here I'm on my main overview landing
page and we see quick links to Common
views for example I can see my cluster
utilization by each physical resource
here
I can see my active nodes here my recent
jobs as well as any events such as Auto
scaling activity and I can inspect each
of these further
let's go to the jobs tab now so that we
can look at this in further detail
I can click into any one of my jobs and
I can access more information about the
state of my tasks nodes resources and
more I'll leave a more thorough
walkthrough of each of these features
for another video but generally this
view offers a rich insight into your
array cluster with popular features like
a task progression breakdown so I can
click in here and look at all of my
tasks that have run in this job as well
as what their statuses are
I can access a task timeline which is
supported by the perfetto UI so I can
download a trace file for this job and I
can take a look at the timeline of tasks
as well as take a look at summary tables
for tasks
actors as well as placement groups
wherever relevant
let's move on now to the cluster tab
I can view my active and inactive nodes
you can use this tab to make sure that
your cluster is running smoothly and to
diagnose any issues that might come up
for example you might notice that a node
is unexpectedly using a lot of CPU or
memory and you might need to take steps
to debug or optimize performance by
looking at logs stack traces or flame
graphs
next let's take a look at the actors tab
this tab shows you the actors that have
existed and if you inspect each you can
find more metadata as well as a history
of tasks that are associated with it
one of the most useful tabs is going to
be this metrics tab which integrates
with grafana to provide several
visualizations that can help you
understand what's happening in your
cluster
for example you can inspect real-time
data on your tasks and actors to view
their status you can look at the ray
resource usage to see how Rey is using
available resources as well as Hardware
utilization to see activity by node
finally Ray dashboard also allows access
to logs which you're able to filter and
search to find what you're looking for
in order to diagnose whatever issues
you're curious about
so that wraps up our quick tour of the

navigate the main views of the dashboard
as well as giving you a high level
overview of some of the most useful
